assessmentPillars.title: Strategy & Governance
assessmentPillars.description: Assess how AI aligns with your business vision and strategic objectives
questions: How often are AI projects evaluated and funded based on their direct, quantifiable contribution to the organization's top-line revenue or bottom-line cost savings?
What is the current state of your organization's commitment to the ethical and responsible use of AI?
How automated and reliable is the process for moving a finalized AI model from development to live production use?
To what extent have operational teams integrated AI outputs (predictions, recommendations) into their daily decision-making workflows?

0.Initial: AI projects are experimental pilots, funded separately, with no required link to core business KPIs.
0.Adopting: AI projects must articulate a potential business impact, but tracking and accountability are inconsistent.
0.Established: Every new AI initiative requires a formal business case linking it to a major KPI (e.g., 5% reduction in churn).
0.Advanced: AI project performance is reviewed quarterly by executive leadership against the original business case and KPI targets.
0.Transformational: AI impact is integrated into the official financial forecasting/budgeting system and is a mandatory component of multiple departmental strategic plans.

1.Initial: We are aware of the risks but have no formal policies or review processes in place.
1.Adopting: We have a draft document of principles/guidelines, but adherence is voluntary and decentralized.
1.Established: We have a formal, documented policy on bias, transparency, and fairness that all AI teams must follow.
1.Advanced: A dedicated AI Ethics/Review Board or a similar cross-functional committee must formally approve all models before production deployment.
1.Transformational: Responsible AI metrics (e.g., bias auditing, explainability scores) are automatically tracked, monitored in production, and integrated into the model's performance KPIs.

2.Initial: Deployment is a manual, one-off process handled primarily by the data scientist who built the model.
2.Adopting: We use basic scripts/templates, but deployment often requires manual configuration and significant IT involvement.
2.Established: We have a standardized CI/CD pipeline (MLOps) for model packaging, testing, and automated staging deployment.
2.Advanced: The pipeline includes automated production monitoring for model performance, data drift, and latency with automated alerting.
2.Transformational: We utilize fully automated, containerized deployment with automated rollbacks/shadow deployment and A/B testing capabilities managed by the MLOps platform.

3.Initial: AI outputs are only used occasionally, typically as background reports or in isolated proof-of-concepts.
3.Adopting: AI provides insights that human operators may review but are not mandatory for proceeding with a task.
3.Established: In key processes (e.g., sales, scheduling), AI-generated recommendations are presented as the default action, requiring a human override to reject.
3.Advanced: AI decisions are automatically executed in some non-critical workflows (e.g., inventory restocking) without direct human intervention.
3.Transformational: AI models operate in a tight feedback loop where human overrides are automatically captured and used to retrain/fine-tune the model, continuously improving performance.

assessmentPillars.title: Organization & Workforce
assessmentPillars.description: Understand your culture, adaptability, and readiness for transformation
questions: How prepared is the workforce to adopt AI tools?
Are clinicians trained to understand AI-generated insights?
Are there AI literacy programs for operational staff?
Do cross-functional teams exist (clinical + data science)?
Is there a defined AI Center of Excellence?
How well are change-management processes established?

assessmentPillars.title: Data & Technology
assessmentPillars.description: Evaluate your data infrastructure and technology capabilities
questions: How standardized and interoperable is clinical data?
How mature are data quality processes?
How well integrated are EHR, LIS, RIS, and PACS systems?
Does the organization maintain a centralized clinical data lake?
Are imaging datasets stored in AI-ready formats?

assessmentPillars.title: Performance & Impact
assessmentPillars.description: Measuring and demonstrating AI value and outcomes
questions: Is there a framework for measuring AI project outcomes?
Is AI used for clinical performance improvement?
Does AI reduce operational burden (wait times, triage)?
Are outcome dashboards available for leadership?
Is predictive analytics used for risk reduction?

assessmentPillars.title: Trust, Ethics & Responsible AI
assessmentPillars.description: Ethical AI practices and responsible deployment
questions: Are AI models tested for clinical fairness?
Is patient consent obtained where required?
Is AI use transparent to patients?
Are ethical risks assessed before deployment?
Are explainability tools used for decision support?

assessmentPillars.title: Security & Risk
assessmentPillars.description: AI security and risk management practices
questions: Are AI systems protected under cybersecurity policies?
Is access to AI systems role-based?
Are AI pipelines monitored for vulnerabilities?
Is sensitive data encrypted end-to-end?
Is there a risk register for AI deployments?
